content.title: First Rib Resection
content.definition: Surgical excision of the first rib to decompress the thoracic outlet, performed for thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) to relieve compression of the subclavian vessels and brachial plexus.

concepts.definition: When first rib resection is indicated.

clinical_features.arterial_tos: Subclavian artery stenosis, aneurysm, or embolization
clinical_features.neurogenic_tos: Selected cases after failed conservative therapy (controversial)

concepts.definition: Different surgical approaches for first rib resection.

clinical_features.transaxillary: Most common, through axilla, limited exposure
clinical_features.infraclavicular: For combined procedures with subclavian access

clinical_features.position: Lateral decubitus with arm in traction
clinical_features.dissection: Identify and protect intercostobrachial, T1 nerve root
clinical_features.scalene_division: Divide anterior and middle scalene muscle insertions
clinical_features.rib_removal: Resect first rib from costochondral junction to transverse process

clinical_features.brachial_plexus_injury: T1 root most vulnerable, arm weakness
clinical_features.pneumothorax: Common, usually managed with chest tube
clinical_features.chylothorax: Thoracic duct injury on left side

clinical_features.timing: For venous TOS, within 2 weeks of thrombolysis optimal

sources.reference: Illig KA et al. J Vasc Surg. 2016;64:e77-e115
Thompson RW et al. Perspect Vasc Surg. 2007;19:34-45
